Package wt.audit

Provides the classes and interfaces for the audit framework.

See: Description

    Class Description
    _AuditEventType  
    AuditEventType
    Enumeration with possible event types.
    AuditHelper
    Helper class for Windchill's audit framework.
    AuditRecord
    Represents an audit event recorded by the audit service (additional data for specific events are represented by the wt.audit.eventinfo.EventInfo interface).

Package wt.audit Description

Provides the classes and interfaces for the audit framework.

The audit framework provides event-based logging that provides a historical record of who did what that caused changes in the Windchill database. This provides historical records of security related events, such as logins, privilege changes, team changes, and denial of access.

Selection of the recorded events is based on the event type and the object type. This is configurable by customers via the ConfigAudit.xml file (See the Windchill Business Administration guide).

Architectural Principles

  • Immutable. Once persisted to the database, audited data describing an audited event is not updated or selectively deleted. Auditing data may be purged based on date, but not based on any other attributes of the auditing data.

  • Implementation-Independent. There can be no assumptions made about how, where, or when the auditing data is persisted. Currently. the auditing data is synchronously persisted in the run-time database, but this is not guaranteed and may change in future releases of Windchill. Therefore, Windchill solutions should not incorporate the use of audit data in their application.

  • Run-time Optimized. Within reason, the end-users' Windchill experience should not be negatively affected if auditing is enabled, at the expense of reporting performance. The auditing framework for capturing event information must be as light and non-intrusive as possible.

  • Transparent. Auditors and administrators should be provided an unfettered view of the auditing data and allowed to draw their own conclusions. No assumptions about the meaning or use of audit data should be made that might cause the audit reports to hide, filter, reformat, or otherwise alter the data presented in the report. Any localization should be carefully considered before implementing.

  • Accurate. The audit data presented in an audit report must be accurate and unambiguous to assist an auditor or administrator in drawing correct conclusions. Audit reports which present foreign data – data not captured by the auditing framework when the audited event was initially emitted – might misrepresent the true state of the application.
